title.narrative: WEL - National Dialogue on two thirds principle

description.narrative: There has been heated debate on the viability of article 81 (b) of the Constitution of Kenya 2010 which requires the not more than two-thirds of the members of elective and appointive public bodies shall be of the same gender. Much has been centered on th e modalities of implementing this provisionDespite Kenya having what has been termed as one of the most progressive Constitutions in the world much is yet to be attained especially in regards to an enabling environment for women's political participation. Compared to the rest of Eastern Africa Kenya has the least number of women in Parliament. The gender equality bill is a great milestone and is provided in the Bill of Rights.Many Kenyans are not aware of Affirmative Action within the Constitution and the resultant effects of this provision on women's political leadership in the society. A study conducted between 28th + 7th April on the Gender rule showed that only 4 out of 10 Kenyans (39%) are aware of the gender rule and what it entails and that there wer e more men than women who knew about the principle - 45% and 33% respectively. It is worthwhile to note that of those polled 66% of Kenyans are of the view that the quality of leadership and governance will improve if women were at least one third of the p arliament. It is in this regard that Women's Empowerment Link in partnership with the media of Kenya seeks to undertake a national debate on the five proposed bills tabled in the National Assembly and the Senate
